moves.1. e4 e6 2. Nf3 c5 3. Bc4 a6 4. O-O b5: Black gains a tempo here because of the position of White's B.
moves.5. Be2 Bb7 6. d3 Nf6 7. Bg5 Be7 8. Nbd2: Both Black and White are fully developed.  Now the maneuvering begins.
moves.11... h6 12. Bh4 Re8 13. c4 b4: If Black plays bxc4, he will isolate his a-pawn and also give White's N a nice spot on c4.
moves.14. axb4 cxb4 15. h3 Nc5: Now Black is the one who gets the good square.
moves.16. Bg3 e5 17. Nh4: The Nh4 is loose.  It is protected once (B), but attacked twice (B+Q).  Right now those pieces are shielded, but they can be unleased.
moves.17... Nfxe4: Black wins a pawn with a discovered attack on the N.
moves.20. Nxe4 Bxe4 21. Bf3 Bxf3 22. Qxf3 Be7: Black is now two pawns to the good.  Black's d-pawn is backward and a target, but White's B is not a very good piece right now.
moves.31. Qg3 Kh7: Now the Rh4 has no safe squares.
moves.32. Rg4 h5 33. Rh4 gxh4 34. Qxh4: Now Black is up considerable material--at the cost of an exposed K.
moves.34... Re6 35. Re1 Qg6 36. f3: exf6 might have been better.  It doesn't lead to the loss of the exposed Re3.  If exf6 and White plays Rxe3, Qxg2# is satisfactory!
moves.36... e3 37. g4 Kg7 38. Bg1 Rce5 39. f4: Now White's K is also exposed and the f4 pawn is loose.
moves.39... Qe4+ 40. Kh2 Qxf4+ 41. Kg2 hxg4 42: It's to Black's advantage to trade.
moves.43. Kxg3 gxh3 44. Kf4 Kg6 45. Kg4 Rg5+ 4: This mistake is fatal.  White's K is now trapped against the edge of the board.
moves.46... Re7: White resigned in view of the unstoppable Rh7# coming next.
